message: On January 6, 1912, New Mexico was admitted to the United States as the 47th state. Happy Birthday New Mexico!

Worried about what happens to the 360,000 New Mexicans who gained health care through Medicaid and the ACA if the law is repealed?  Join me on Sunday, January 15 at 2 PM at the Unitarian Universalist (107 W Barcelona Rd, Santa Fe, New Mexico) for a discussion, sponsored by Health Action New Mexico, about potential changes to the health insurance marketplace, including plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act, dismantle Medicaid, and privatize Medicare.

My reaction to President Trump’s executive order banning immigration and halting admission of refugees:  “President Trump has not only hardened his heart against the obvious suffering of refugees fleeing persecution, destruction and carnage in their homeland, he also ignores the lessons of history. Last century, as Jews were being systematically murdered in Europe, the U.S. had a chance to admit those fleeing the Holocaust, and did virtually nothing. History will not judge the Trump administration favorably for slamming the door in the face of refugees of this century who are desperately trying to keep themselves and their families alive.  The President's move could hamper our nation in the fight against terrorism and will degrade our standing in the eyes of the world. We need smart and tough strategies to keep our nation safe, not reckless, dangerous, and unconstitutional policies.”

Today’s hearing in the House Health Subcommittee was touted as the first step in an effort to replace the Affordable Care Act. According to the President, the Republican replacement bill is “formulated down to the final strokes.” And that it will include “lower [premium] numbers,” and “much lower deductibles.”   This was not a bill crafted down to the final strokes!  What our committee was given was 7 pages of bill text and a placeholder (read it for yourself here: http://docs.house.gov/meetings/IF/IF14/20170202/105506/BILLS-115pih-PreexistingConditionsProtectionandContinuousCoverageIncentiveActof2017.pdf). That’s not a replacement plan; that’s a rough draft of a rough draft – at best.   Republicans have had 7 years to come up with a replacement plan for the Affordable Care Act and our committee was presented with a half-written bill. The President and elected officials from his party keep promising that their replacement bill will provide the same protections to patients as the ACA, and give them better access to health insurance and “lower numbers,” and “much lower deductibles.”  Where in the legislative language given to us today are these patient protections? Where are the lower costs? Where are these lower deductibles? I will tell you where – they are nowhere! The only group that benefits by these proposals are the insurance companies, because it puts them back in charge.  I was a brand new Member of Congress when we started working to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2009. At the time, my Republican colleagues went to the floor and laughed that this bill was longer than the bible. They said they didn’t have time to read it or study it and frankly, I think they thought Democrats were foolish because this legislation was as lengthy as it was. But now they’re realizing that the Affordable Care Act was long because health care is complicated and the ACA was thorough. Republicans are finding out now what we learned years ago: you can’t fit the details of a real plan to make healthcare more affordable and life better for American families in a tweet.   When we debated the ACA, we were honest with the American people about how complex this undertaking. Unfortunately, my Republican colleagues sabotaged this bill every step of the way. And now we come to this. Claims that this replacement plan will preserve  protections for patients and provide lower health care costs for the American people and we get 7 pages and a placeholder. Is this really all you’ve got?

Congressman Luján will be holding two Town Hall Meetings in the coming week to discuss healthcare and the Affordable Care Act. Please join us!  Saturday, February 18th , 2017 ACA Town Hall El Centro Family Health Clinic 15136 State Road 75, Penasco, NM 87553  3-4PM  Saturday, February 25th, 2017 ACA Town Hall/Open Office Hours Boys and Girls Club of Santa Fe 6600 Valentine Way, Santa Fe  10AM to 12PM

If you’ve ever heard that old saying “Buyer Beware” – it definitely applies to the Republican Repeal Plan we are starting to hear about from Washington. Find out more in this commentary that ran over the weekend. http://www.santafenewmexican.com/opinion/commentary/commentary-beware-the-gop-health-plans/article_d41b396f-3c72-548c-a537-7f7f8e4279ee.html
We have had packed houses at all of the town halls we’ve held across northern New Mexico so far. Our next one is coming up this Saturday. Hope to see you there! #ProtectOurCare

We have just added a new town hall in Rio Rancho this Saturday to discuss healthcare. Hope to see you there!  Rio Rancho High School  Performing Arts Center 301 Loma Colorado DR NE, Rio Rancho, NM 2:00pm – 4:00pm

Thank you to the hundreds of people who came out to my two town hall meetings this weekend. It was good to talk with the so many folks in our district, hear their concerns and thoughts and answer as many questions as I could. The high attendance at my  town halls and similar  meetings across the country demonstrates the power of democracy. The opinions of our constituents do matter. Never forget public officials answer to you and your voices have the power to change things. I am always reminded of that famous Margaret Mead quote – “Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has.”  Thank you all for taking an active role in your government!  http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/health_and_science/hundreds-gather-in-opposition-to-health-law-repeal-at-santa/article_c74e47ae-6451-5174-b1bd-9f64d255a238.html

All Presidential budgets are a reflection of that particular Administration’s goals and priorities, and this one is no different. President Trump is proposing a federal budget that dramatically cuts critical federal programs like education, environmental protection, and nutrition assistance. Unfortunately those cuts – coupled with tax reductions that favor the wealthy and tax increases that hurt middle-class and working families– show how far off the mark the President’s priorities for the country truly are.

Last night we saw President Trump in full pitchman mode as he tried to defend the turmoil and chaos that’s plagued his administration over the past 40 days and attempted to sell the nation on his Trump-centric view of the path forward. I think we’ve all heard this type of fast and loose sales pitch before – but it’s what we have come to expect from snake oil salesmen, not the President of the United States!”  His rhetoric last night may have been adjusted by his speechwriters to seem more bipartisan, but the President’s actions so far have not offered any common ground on anything – it has all been ‘his way or the highway.’ That’s not democracy.  When it comes to big issues like healthcare, the President can’t continue selling Congress and the American people a bundle of vague promises that bear no resemblance to the heartless and short-sighted policy proposals his allies in Congress are putting forward. If the President wants to finance his healthcare plan by backing a tax increase that will hit more middle-class families and more small businesses than any previous tax in history; that concerns me, but let’s have that debate openly and honestly. Don’t come before Congress and say you’re looking out for working Americans, while your Republican cronies in the front row of the House chamber have proposed raising taxes on those very families.

It is simply unacceptable that Attorney General Jeff Sessions lied under oath about his communications with Russian officials. His role as our nation’s top law enforcement official has been compromised and he should do the right thing and resign. Failing that, President Trump should fire him immediately, just as he fired his National Security Advisor when it was found he lied to the Vice President about his contact with the Russians.”  Virtually every day, new information emerges that underscores the need for an independent investigation into President Trump’s personal, political, and financial ties to the Russians. The American people deserve answers and it is time to proceed with a fair, independent investigation to follow the facts wherever they lead. Honesty, and truthfulness are fundamental components of an effective democracy, and an independent investigation will ensure these ideals supersede politics.  The Trump Administration should immediately come clean with who else had contact with the Russians, when that contact occurred, what was discussed, and what promises were made. Anything less does not further justice, instead it thwarts it.

Attention NM small business owners: The US Department of Agriculture is holding a workshop in Albuquerque on Thursday, March 9, 2017 to help small rural businesses access funding.  Small businesses in New Mexico can learn more about applying for federal funding for training or technical assistance activities, as well as grants to help acquire or develop land, buildings, and equipment or establish a revolving loan fund.  This workshop is free and open to the public.  Please see images of the USDA press release below for more details.    For a description of the RBDG program: https://www.rd.usda.gov/programs-services/rural-business-development-grants.

This Friday I along with 164 of my colleagues signed a letter urging for the release of President Trump’s tax returns. Every President in the modern era has disclosed their tax returns and there should be no exception with President Trump. I believe it is the right of all Americans to understand how their elected officials are financially contributing towards the government and to ensure there are no conflicts between what’s good for the public and what’s good for their own self-interests. Putting information in the hands of the people and transparency from those who hold a public trust are what keep our government accountable and is a cornerstone of American democracy. President Trump must do the right thing – the responsible thing – and release his tax returns.

The Affordable Care Act was implemented after 79 bipartisan hearings and markups in the House. The House GOP Leadership wants to push their bill through in ONE day. They only unveiled their bill 72 hours ago and have provided no cost projections or estimates of its full impact. What we know so far: it provides less coverage to fewer people at higher costs. It puts 235,000+ New Mexicans at risk of losing their current health coverage. I have been debating the bill in committee all day so far and I'm determined to stay here and make them explain the details of this sad excuse for a bill for as long as it takes.

Took a few minutes to step outside the hearing room where we have been debating the GOP Repeal bill for the past 27+ hours to meet with Mike D’Arco from Albuquerque, a member & officer Paralyzed Veterans of America, and past state commander of the American Legion New Mexico. The New Mexico Paralyzed Veterans of America provides veterans service, medical research and civil rights for people with disabilities. Mike was in Washington to discuss health care for our veterans and other legislative priorities for New Mexico veterans. Had a very good meeting with Mike and his wife (even if we had to pull up some seats out in the hallway.) Thanks to Mike and his fellow veterans for their service and sacrifice!

I want to offer my prayers and deepest condolences to the family of Officer Houston Largo, who made the ultimate sacrifice in the line of duty. My heart goes out to his family, friends and law enforcement colleagues. All of us in New Mexico are deeply grateful for Officer Largo’s dedicated service and the unwavering commitment of our men and women in uniform who risk their lives every day to dutifully protect our citizens. We all honor his service and sacrifice and grieve for his family, and we will keep them all in our thoughts and prayers.

I am deeply saddened by the loss of Major Andrew Becker, Captain Kenneth Dalga and Captain Frederick Dellecker, the airmen who recently lost their lives in a training flight from Cannon Air Force Base. To their families and loved ones, please know you continue to be in my thoughts and prayers. The outpouring of emotion and support from Cannon Air Base personnel at the memorial yesterday demonstrates how deeply this tragedy has affected us all. Words cannot express how profoundly grateful we all are to these young airmen who made the ultimate sacrifice in the service of our country.

Today I was proud to stand with former Vice President Joe Biden, House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi, Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer and more than 100 of my fellow House Democrats to mark 7 years since President Obama signed the Affordable Care Act into law. Since the Affordable Care Act became law, more than 20 million previously uninsured Americans have gained access to quality, affordable health care, and more than 155 million additional Americans who receive health insurance through their employers have benefitted from the law’s historic protections. Tomorrow, House Republicans will try to undo the progress we have made by promoting legislation that raises health costs for your family, including premiums, deductibles and copays; imposes an age tax on you if you’re  50 and older; and will strip away healthcare from millions of Americans. We must protect our healthcare!

Essential Health Benefits require insurance companies to provide coverage for doctor’s visits, ER visits, hospitalizations, prescription drugs. So the question is, if you’re buying health insurance and not getting these things, what are you paying for?   Before the ACA, many Americans bought insurance only to find out that it did not cover necessary care, such as prescription drugs or hospitalization. Under the ACA, all Qualified Health Plans must cover a set of services, known as Essential Health Benefits – providing reassurance to millions of Americans that the health services they need to keep their families and themselves healthy are covered when they buy insurance.  What’s guaranteed?  • Ambulatory patient services (doctor’s visits) • Emergency services • Hospitalization • Maternity and newborn care • Mental health and substance abuse disorder services, including behavioral health treatment • Prescription drugs • Rehabilitative and habilitative services and devices • Laboratory services • Preventive and wellness services, and chronic disease management • Pediatric services, including oral and vision care  Stripping EHBs is a backdoor way to allow health insurers to discriminate against people with pre-existing conditions.   If they succeed in eliminating EHBs:  •  Insurers could make their benefits bare-bones, dropping benefits entirely or dramatically limiting benefits likely used by those with chronic/serious illness. •  People with pre-existing conditions would not actually be able to purchase plans that cover the benefits they need. It would again allow insurance companies to say “we cover asthma” but not be required to cover any asthma medication. Or “we cover maternal care” but not be required to cover c-sections.  •  In effect, insurers could design benefit packages in such a way as to discourage people with pre-existing conditions from enrolling in the first place.   The purpose of the EHB is threefold:  1. to ensure that coverage provides access to essential health care;  2. to minimize abuse in which insurers design benefits to attract healthier individuals and deter less healthy individuals; and  3. to provide some degree of standardization to make it easier for consumers and small businesses to make apples-to-apples comparisons of plans—which empowers consumers and enhances competition based on price and quality.  Before the ACA: • Only 12 percent of plans on the individual marketplace covered maternity services. In 2011, 62 percent of individual market enrollees did not have maternity coverage. • Nearly two-thirds of people covered through their employer had special limits on inpatient behavioral health services. About one-quarter required higher levels of cost sharing for behavioral health care.  https://www.abqjournal.com/974432/pearce-leaning-no-on-gop-health-plan.html

With midnight deals and pledges to make TrumpCare even more destructive to Americans’ health care, Congressional Republicans continue to barrel toward voting to increase Americans’ health costs and take away health coverage for millions of Americans.    It’s the morning of the vote, and President Trump and Speaker Ryan have made massive, destructive changes to TrumpCare without any debate, with no transparency and without a CBO score to show the budgetary impact of what they are doing to millions of American families.  Floor consideration of the newest version of TrumpCare comes as new polling shows that Americans oppose the bill by a 3 to 1 margin, 56 to 17 percent in polling out yesterday.    •  Higher Costs – TrumpCare forces families to pay higher premiums and deductibles, increasing out-of-pocket costs.  •  Less Coverage – TrumpCare will take away health care from 24 million hard-working Americans.  •  A Crushing Age Tax – TrumpCare forces Americans aged 50-64 to pay premiums five times higher than what others pay for health coverage, no matter how healthy they are.  •  Key Protections Gutted – TrumpCare bill would eradicate Essential Health Benefits, such as maternity, Rx drug and emergency coverage, functionally destroying protections for Americans with pre-existing conditions.  •  Steals from Medicare – TrumpCare shortens the life of the Medicare Trust Fund and ransacks funds that seniors depend on to get the long-term care they need.

My Republican colleagues have called Trumpcare everything from an act of mercy to a rescue mission.   Look, I might live at the end of a long dirt road, but I didn’t fall off the turnip truck yesterday. And neither did the American people!   Congressional Republicans are jamming through their catastrophic bill that will take health insurance away from 24 million Americans, raise your premiums, raise your deductibles, raise your out of pocket costs, and will slap a crushing age tax on those over the age of 50.   Republicans in Congress promised they would lower costs. But this mess raises costs on families. Not only does the CBO tells us premiums will increase 15 to 20%, but Trumpcare will allow insurance companies to increase deductibles and out-of-pocket costs.   Under the guise of state flexibility, Republicans say they are shifting responsibility to states. Here’s what that means. Trumpcare will force states to raise taxes and ration care.  It will repeal the requirement for insurance plans to cover doctor’s visits, Emergency Room care, prescription drug coverage and even mental health services.   Everyone is entitled to their own opinions, but not their own facts.   The fact is, Trumpcare will raise your premiums, raise your deductibles, and hurt millions of hardworking families.  I urge my colleagues to vote no

Why I am voting ‘no’ on attempt to repeal internet privacy rules:  Today, the House will consider S.J. Res. 34, a resolution under the Congressional Review Act to that will remove the 2016 Federal Communications Commission (FCC) rule that protects Americans’ personal information, internet browsing history and other private data from being sold to advertisers and other third parties without their knowledge and to require internet service providers (ISPs) take reasonable measures to protect consumers from hackers.   S.J. Res. 34 passed the Senate last week along a party-line vote with all Democrats voting NO. This week it is being brought to the House floor without any committee hearings or prior debate.  I am voting no on this bill because I believe Americans should have the right to decide how their internet providers use their personal information. S.J. Res. 34 would undo these FCC rules protecting consumers’ location, financial, and health information as well as information about children, Social Security numbers, and content of communications, including email.   House Republicans want to give ISPs the right to gather and monetize personal information from consumers using the internet on their networks.  The implications of collecting Americans’ data are wide ranging. From the New York Times, internet providers  "can tell the time people wake up by when they check the clock on their phone, or see where users go to lunch or whom they visit. By tracking a user’s browsing of medical websites, a carrier can also determine if that person might have an illness.” (https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/23/technology/congress-moves-to-strike-internet-privacy-rules-from-obama-era.html?_r=2)  S.J. Res. 34 jeopardizes Americans’ privacy now and in the future. If this resolution is signed into law, the FCC may be unable to act in the future to adopt new rules to protect consumers’ privacy and ensure personal sensitive information remains secure. This bill is a sledgehammer that completely nullifies FCC action and the specific legislative language prevents rules “in substantially the same form” from being adopted in the future.

President Trump on Wednesday signed an executive order to address the opioid epidemic. The executive order creates a commission, to be headed by New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, that will recommend what steps should be taken. The President’s Commission on Combating Drug Addiction and the Opioid Crisis will focus on putting together a report, due in the fall, on the opioid crisis and potential solutions to it. The commission will identify existing federal funding for the epidemic, identify places that have limited drug treatment options, review opioid addiction prevention strategies, and make recommendations to the president to improve the federal response to addiction and the opioid crisis.  Today I sent a letter to Governor Christie, urging him to prioritize funding for drug treatment and prevention initiatives as the commission begins its work. The text of my letter is below:

They are truly inspirational. Check them out!  https://youtu.be/N0noHNXEk5Y

Got a chance to talk to Hope, Gay and Elena about critical priorities for the Down syndrome community. (Pictured below, from left to right: Hope Young, me, Elena Romero and Gay Romero)

I was pleased to join my Congressional colleagues Rep. Michelle Lujan Grisham and Rep. Steve Pearce today as we participated in a panel discussion at the Greater Albuquerque Chamber of Commerce’s annual Congressional Luncheon series. Topics included healthcare, education, immigration and tax reform.   https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1060422417434610&id=191640657646128&_rdr

Today marks the start of an annual event for thousands in New Mexico – the pilgrimage walk leading to El Santuario de Chimayó for Good Friday. Whether you’re considering walking yourself or if you will be driving major roads in the area around Chimayó during the next few days, local law enforcement and health officials offer the following tips –   For pilgrims: Law enforcement officials from Santa Fe and Rio Arriba counties remind walkers to dress in layered clothing and comfortable shoes, walk against traffic, stay off the roadway and the medians, keep animals on a leash and keep children close. Don’t forget to bring water, snacks and protection against the sun. If walking at night, bring a flashlight and wear bright or reflective clothing and carry glow sticks. The Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office says deputies will distribute glow sticks to walkers after 6 p.m. Thursday at exit 168 on U.S. 84/285 at south Tesuque, U.S. 84/285 at N.M. 503, and the intersection of N.M. 106 and N.M. 76.   For drivers: Starting on Thursday (4/13), the Santa Fe County Sheriff’s Office will increase patrols and set up DWI checkpoints. Drivers should keep an eye out for walkers, drive slowly in the vicinity of pilgrims, and keep as far away from the shoulders of the road as possible.

This week state lawmakers approved the Hunger-Free Students’ Bill of Rights Act, making New Mexico the first state to officially put an end to school lunch shaming. Now every student regardless of their circumstances will be able to receive a school lunch. It is fantastic to see our state taking the first step – and the right step –  on this important issue. Education is vital to our state’s future and students should have access to all the tools they need to succeed, including a hot school lunch.   https://www.abqjournal.com/986343/school-lunch-bill-strikes-chord.html

Had a great day visiting Mesalands Community College to learn more about the college’s wind energy program which prepare students for jobs in the wind energy sector. The North American Wind Research and Training Center at Mesalands is leading the way in wind energy and is ensuring that when Mesalands students graduate, they will do so with the knowledge to be successful in the growing field of wind power. I am introducing legislation in Congress to encourage other community colleges throughout the state and around the country to develop similar programs in the renewable energy sector.  While at Mesalands, I also got to see some students at work in the college art program where I learned more about the silversmithing program and got to see an student team casting aluminum in the college’s casting foundry. Tricky work that these students made look easy! Very impressive!

On April 29th, President Trump will complete his first hundred days in office.  The one hundred-day mark is an important opportunity for all Americans to take stock of a new President – to evaluate his progress, and to measure the accomplishments and shortcomings of his administration.  Sadly, it seems like President Trump has spent more time golfing than governing. He has broken many of the promises made on the campaign trail, and rather than look for common ground with Democrats or finding bipartisan solutions, he has pushed policies that hurt, rather than help, middle-class families in New Mexico and across the country.  In this week’s Democratic Address, I draw attention to President Trump’s chaotic approach to governing and his worrisome – and often nonexistent – relationship with the truth during his first hundred days in office.

All of these organizations, representing millions of patients, stand opposed to the latest version of the Republican healthcare repeal bill – the American Health Care Act.   In a joint letter, these health groups write:   "Despite potential changes reported in the press this morning, this bill is fundamentally harmful to patients.  Current law protects patients from being charged more for health insurance based on a pre-existing condition. This bill, including the MacArthur and Upton Amendments, would undermine that vital safeguard. The various patches offered by lawmakers—including high risk pools and financial assistance with premiums—do not in any way offer the same level of protection provided in current law.  Moreover, other equally important problems with the bill remain, including:  • Allowing states to waive the guarantee of essential health benefits, segmenting the market into plans for sick people and plans for healthy people—which will drive up the cost of plans for people with serious health care needs.   • Waiving essential health benefits also undermines the protection against annual and lifetime coverage caps, a critical safeguard for patients.  • Eliminating Medicaid expansion coverage for millions of Americans and altering the program’s financing structure in a way that jeopardizes coverage of new and innovative treatments.  • Increasing out-of-pocket costs for many Americans, including some of the sickest and elderly among us.  We urge members to oppose the American Health Care Act, including the Upton and MacArthur Amendments.”  Signed:   American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network American Diabetes Association American Heart Association American Lung Association Cystic Fibrosis Foundation JDRF March of Dimes National Multiple Sclerosis Society National Organization for Rare Disorders Women Heart: The National Coalition for Women with Heart Disease

[WASHINGTON, DC] – Congressman Ben Ray Luján (D-NM) today issued the following statement following President Trump’s dismissal of FBI Director James Comey:   “After a hundred days of President Trump’s antics, it has grown harder and harder to be shocked by his behavior. But today I am both shocked and saddened by the President’s termination of FBI Director James Comey. To fire the nation’s chief law enforcement official – especially one who is in the midst of a high profile investigation into connections between the President’s top campaign advisors and agents of the Russian government – is at best irresponsible, and at worst, smacks of a cover-up.   Nearly 45 years ago, Richard Nixon fired the special prosecutor who was conducting the Watergate investigation in what became known as the Saturday Night Massacre. In that case the Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General had the good judgement and decency to resign in protest over the President’s actions. Today, we seem to have an Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General who are willing to support the President no matter how far out of bounds he steps.   Have we really come to this? A President and an administration so desperate to prevent the facts from coming to light that they will stop at nothing to brush a federal investigation under the rug?  Today’s events have made it abundantly clear that it is past time to appoint an independent commission to look into the Russia-Trump connection and follow the facts no matter where they lead. It may also be worthwhile to have an independent examination the President’s and Attorney General’s actions with regard to the dismissal of the FBI Director as well.  No one is above the law -- especially those sworn to uphold it at the highest levels. For the sake of our democracy we must get to the bottom of this mess and restore trust and respect in our government and those who lead it.”

President Trump revealed his true colors with the release of his budget proposal today. He campaigned on restoring jobs and economic fairness to the middle class in small town America, but his budget does the opposite – dramatically cutting critical programs that provide assistance to small towns and rural communities throughout New Mexico; slashing Medicaid by $1.4 trillion which threatens the stability of many small hospitals in our state and jeopardizes the health of more than 19,000 New Mexico veterans who depend on Medicaid for their healthcare and cripples funding for nutrition assistance, education, environmental protection, help for farmers and other services families in New Mexico and across the country depend on just to get by.  Americans didn’t vote to gut healthcare for seniors, the disabled or those in tough economic circumstances, nor did they give the President the green light to ease up on polluters, slash the food stamp program or give Wall Street permission to rip off those who live on Main Street. They certainly didn’t vote to make all these devastating cuts so that President Trump can dole out a tax break to millionaires.  Read more: https://lujan.house.gov/press-releases/lujan-says-trump-budget-will-be-devastating-for-new-mexico/

Was proud and honored to pay tribute to the men and women who wear this country's uniform today. As we honor the memories  valor, and sacrifice of the men and women we’ve lost, we must also fulfill our nation’s promise to those who live.  Got a chance to meet some amazing military families and spend some time with Johnny Washington and Thomas Creeham from the American Legion at Lawn Haven Memorial Gardens in Clovis after the ceremonies.

Was able to stop in at the New Mexico Boy’s State program this afternoon to talk with the participants. Boy’s State is a program of the American Legion that helps high school students better understand and appreciate the basic principles involved in the successful operation of a democratic society. Boys State is a special summer time program that focuses on participation and personal experience. It is designed to mirror the structure and operation of our state government ,complete with governing bodies and elected public officials.  Was great to see so many eager, engaged and enthusiastic students taking part in the program today!

Congratulations to Los Alamos Topper Academy freshman Lillian Petersen who competed last month in the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) in Los Angeles, California. Petersen was awarded third place honors and a $1,000 scholarship by Intel  for her project in the Earth and Environmental Sciences category. Petersen’s award winning project is entitled, America's Farming Future: The Impact of Climate Change on Crop Yields.  Also competing at the Intel ISEF were Los Alamos High School juniors Sophia Li, Priyanka Velappan and Alex Ionkov. The four Los Alamos students and their adult sponsors won all expense paid trips to the competition.  More than 1,700 young scientists, engineers and mathematicians gathered in Los Angeles, where they participated in the world’s largest pre-college science competition, the 2017 Intel International Science and Engineering Fair.

Congratulations to Dr. Barbara McAneny who was just elected president of the American Medical Association (AMA).  Dr. McAneny will assume the office of AMA president in June 2018 following a year-long term as president-elect. This is the first time in the 170 year history of the AMA that a New Mexican has been elected to lead the organization.  Dr. McAneny is co-founder and CEO of New Mexico Oncology Hematology Consultants, and also founded and manages the New Mexico Cancer Center, which provides comprehensive outpatient medical and radiation oncology care and imaging in several underserved rural areas across New Mexico including sites in Albuquerque and Gallup.  The American Medical Association is the premier national association for physicians with more than 215,000 members. It was founded in 1847 and incorporated in 1897.  Because Dr. McAneny’s practice has focused on medically underserved areas in New Mexico which rely heavily on Medicaid, she will bring an important perspective to the national healthcare debate. The AMA recently announced strong opposition to the per capita caps on federal Medicaid funding contained in President Trump’s health care legislation.   Dr. McAneny has also testified as an expert witness before Congress and I can say without a doubt that she is a powerful and forceful advocate for cancer patients in our state and across the country. Congratulations, Dr. McAneny on this well-deserved honor!

IMPORTANT SAFETY INFORMATION FOR SANDOVAL COUNTY:  The Cajete fire continues to burn and is estimated to now be over 700 acres.   State Police are currently handling road closure security as Highway 4 remains closed to through traffic north of the intersection of Highway 126 and south of MM 36. The road is expected to remain closed throughout the night and into tomorrow.   The Jemez Baptist Church in La Cueva has been established as a refuge for those who did not have other places to go.   Sandoval County Sherriff’s office is continuing to assist to escort homeowners into certain areas to retrieve their pets and animals where safe to do so. A Sheriff's Office supervisor and 2 or 3 deputies will remain at the command post for ready response to an emergency.  Residents are to meet Sandoval County Sheriff’s Deputies at mile marker 27 on highway 4 to get escorted located on the west side of the fire.  The media is being advised when important updates are known and have been helpful in sharing that information with the public. Firefighters are doing their best to get the fire under control and we wish them safety and success.  Stay tuned to your local news outlet and here is some information and resources to stay up to date on the fire:  USFS FIRE UPDATE HOTLINE 505-438-5499  USFS Main line 505-438-1500  SANDOVAL COUNTY SHERIFF’S OFFICE 505-867-7526  Updates will be posted on the New Mexico Fire Information website at nmfireinfo.com and on @SantaFeNFand www.facebook.com/SantaFeNF

The CBO has now confirmed what we suspected all along: the Senate health bill is just as mean and heartless as the one Congressional Republicans jammed through the House earlier this year. Not only would 22 million Americans lose coverage, Medicaid would also be cut by $772 billion over the next decade – effectively stripping more than 235,000 New Mexicans of health insurance. We must stand up and be counted – all senators Republicans and Democrats – should vote no on #Trumpcare.

Two years ago today, the Supreme Court ruled that marriage equality is the law of the land. On this anniversary, I am glad to see that the Supreme Court has affirmed today that all couples must be treated equally. As we continue the fight, we remember that #LoveIsLove.

I had the opportunity to meet with some of New Mexico’s future leaders in science and technology- students from Alamogordo and Socorro who participate in FIRST Robotics Competitions. FIRST engages young people in mentor-based programs that build science, engineering, and technology skills, that inspire innovation, and that foster well-rounded life capabilities including self-confidence, communication, and leadership.

During an Energy and Commerce Committee hearing today I took the opportunity to remind my colleagues in Congress of our obligation to our nation’s uranium workers. Watch the clip below and visit my website for more information on legislation I have introduced to expand compensation for those exposed to radiation while working in uranium mines or living downwind from atomic weapons tests.

I met with the winner of this year's Congressional Art Competition- Emily Jones from Los Alamos High School. Her work will be displayed in the U.S. Capitol for an entire year where it can be seen by the millions of visitors from across the world who visit the capitol building. Emily is a New Mexico native who has always had a passion for art, which was cultivated at a young age. From her earliest memories, Emily has been inspired by the beautiful surroundings her home state. While she enjoys all forms of art, one of Emily’s favorite artistic mediums falls within the digital realm. Emily currently uses a mix of traditional and digital methods to create unique digital characters and settings. Her winning butterfly entry was created completely on her tablet, and then printed on a color printer for display.

This month, members of my staff will be holding Mobile Office Hours in your area to address any issues or concerns you may have about your community or the federal government. Stop by one of the Mobile Office Hours below or visit one of my district offices any time. We look forward to seeing you!

Does everything seem slower online today? This is the future of the internet if we don't protect #NetNeutrality. Net Neutrality protects small businesses and innovators in our district by ensuring they have a level playing field online. Say no to online fast-lanes reserved for big corporations and protect Net Neutrality for all.

The Congressional App Challenge is now open for submissions! The Congressional App Challenge was created because Congress recognized that science, math and computer-based skills are essential for economic growth and innovation, and that the U.S. has been falling behind on these fronts. This contest encourages students to pursue those skills and recognizes them for their hard work. The Challenge is a nationwide event, open to students in our district. Students can choose to work together or compete against their peers by creating an “app.” Learn how you can participate by visiting my website: https://lujan.house.gov/press-releases/lujan-announces-that-2017-congressional-app-challenge-is-now-open/  #HouseOfCode #STEMEducation

As part of my commitment to improving the lives of vulnerable children, Congressman Tim Ryan of Ohio and I introduced legislation (HR.3291) to boost funding for early childhood home visiting services. There is considerable evidence that home visiting and pediatric-based services have been extremely successful in preventing adverse childhood experiences such as mistreatment, neglect or sexual abuse. Learn more about the bill on my website.

I was raised to believe that in America, hard work and a good job are all you should need to experience the American dream.  But for that to happen, we must ask if our economy can still deliver on that original American promise. Compared to just a few years ago, millions of Americans do not feel that there’s more opportunity for them today. Nearly half of these individuals say that a sudden $500 expense would be a serious blow to their family’s budget.  Three out of every four say their incomes are not keeping up with the cost of living.  That’s not right, and the American people deserve A Better Deal. One that puts hardworking families first again.  This means rewarding the small business owner for her hard work and entrepreneurship. It means skill training and investing in the future through apprenticeship programs and communities colleges, as well as making four-year college more affordable.  Our nation’s greatest strength is our people: honest, hardworking people from all walks of life. We must respect the dignity of every person – no matter who you are, where you come from, or who you’ve voted for.   And we must have a better economic plan that works for all Americans. A Better Deal.  http://www.democraticleader.gov/abetterdeal/

Substance abuse in the United States is a public health crisis. In 2016, overdose deaths topped 59,000 – rising at the largest annual jump ever recorded. More than 500 of those deaths occurred here in New Mexico. All evidence points to the trend continuing in 2017.  That’s why I have introduced legislation to extend funding to combat the growing public health crisis of opioid-related addiction and deaths. My bill would extend current funding and provide a total of $2.5 billion dollars over five years in the form of a block grant. These grants will support local efforts to provide access to treatment, bolster substance abuse prevention programs, and expand evidence-based initiatives that will help address this deadly epidemic.  Funding for opioid prevention and treatment programs is essential and every dollar counts when it comes to New Mexico’s efforts to combat the opioid epidemic and prevent more lives from being lost. The sad fact remains that much more must be done if we are going to ensure that all those who want help can get help.  Learn more about the bill on my website.

This week, the House of Representatives passed an amendment I introduced that would require the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to prioritize the reimbursement of local communities for environmental infrastructure projects constructed jointly with the Army Corps of Engineers. A number of local governments in New Mexico have financed joint construction projects with the Corps, but have not been fully paid back for work completed.  For too long, local governments in our state have been left holding IOUs from the federal government when doing work with the Army Corps of Engineers. For example, the City of Rio Rancho completed construction of an arsenic treatment facility, but had to wait years before it received a dollar from the Corps. Our amendment will require the Army Corps to make repayment a higher priority and devote more resources to reimbursing local communities. This will help local communities keep their budgets in the black, will get these liabilities off the books of the Army Corps and allow other projects to move forward.  Thank you to my colleague Congresswoman Michelle Lujan Grisham for co-sponsoring this amendment with me.

Congratulations to New Mexico’s National Guard Adjutant General Kenneth Nava on his promotion to the rank of Major General. Major General Nava has served with the New Mexico National Guard for nearly 30 years. I had the pleasure of meeting with Major General Nava in my DC office recently. Please join me in congratulating him on his promotion and thanking him for his years of dedicated service.
If you are in the Santa Fe area next Tuesday, please join me for a town hall meeting where we will discuss topics of interest -- from healthcare to jobs and the economy. Hope to see you there!

Today, I joined more than 75 other members of the House of Representatives in an official censure of President Donald Trump for failing to immediately and specifically name and condemn the white supremacist, Ku Klux Klan, and neo-Nazi groups responsible for acts of domestic terrorism in Charlottesville, Virginia last weekend. President Trump blamed “both sides” for the violence in Charlottesville, excusing the behavior of the participants in the ‘Unite the Right’ rally.  The President of the United States has a responsibility – both in his words and his actions to lead our nation in times of crisis. President Trump’s remarks following the violence in Charlottesville last weekend were morally indefensible. Refusing to completely denounce white supremacist groups and individuals is unacceptable. We must send a clear message to President Trump that his comments are not only shameful, but a betrayal of what this country stands for. It is incumbent on all Members of Congress, from all parties to not only condemn the President’s remarks, but to issue this censure of the President because he has failed to represent our country.  The resolution offers an official censure by Congress of President Trump for his remarks, and calls for the President to fire any and all advisors who have urged him to cater to white supremacist movements in the United States.

Had a great tour of the Navajo Indian Irrigation Project (NIIP) and Navajo Agricultural Products Industry (NAPI) today. My visit today demonstrated what many in New Mexico already knew – NAPI an NIIP are critical economic partners not just for our state but for the region as well.  I continue to be impressed by the work NAPI has done to open up markets for organically grown products – items that are grown using both traditional and innovative approaches. There is no question that the products grown here in New Mexico can compete both nationally and globally. I want to ensure that at the federal level we work to strengthen and expand those market opportunities.

One of the most important duties I have is to listen to the concerns and opinions of those I represent. Today’s town hall with Navajo Nation veterans was a great chance to hear firsthand from veterans on topics from the VA to national security.  I always feel like I walk away from sessions like this better informed and better prepared to debate the issues that matter in Congress.

Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and the families of the tragic shooting at the Clovis –Carver Public Library in Clovis tonight.   While the details are still coming in, we grieve for the innocent victims shot in a senseless act of violence; lives disrupted and futures cut short; and a community reeling. We must come together to heal, but this trend must not continue.

My thoughts and prayers are with all those impacted by the storm damage and flooding from Hurricane Harvey. May God keep and protect those families from further harm. And may god bless and protect the brave first responders and disaster officials working around the clock to save lives.  http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/28/546745827/looking-to-help-those-affected-by-harvey-here-s-a-list

I join so many New Mexicans in mourning the passing of Santa Fe teacher and my friend, Susan Popovich.  It is a profound loss for our state, for Santa Fe, and for all who had the privilege to know her.  Her energy, spirit and good works will live on through all those she touched.

DACA has enabled nearly 800,000 talented young people to contribute more fully to this country. They’re nurses, engineers, small business owners, our friends and our neighbors. These young people came to the United States under the age of 16, some of them only a year or two old. They grew up in the U.S., going to our public schools, singing the Star Spangled Banner, pledging allegiance to the only flag they’ve ever known: the American flag. Since 2012, the 9,000 DREAMers in New Mexico have not had to live in fear of deportation.  If the Trump administration moves ahead with this mean-spirited attempt to repeal DACA, those young people and their families will once again risk being torn apart. I will oppose any attempt by the President to end DACA and rip these young people away from the country in which they have grown up and that they love and respect. Tearing families apart to achieve a political end does not reflect American values and will not solve our immigration problems.

I was deeply saddened to learn of the passing of former State Representative Luciano 'Lucky' Varela.   Lucky made the world a better place. He was loved and respected by all who knew him.  Representative Varela was seen by many as the conscience of the state legislature -- thoughtful, knowledgeable, and always ready to lend a hand to anyone in need. During his 30 years of dedicated service, he became one of New Mexico's most profound political leaders.  His leadership and compassion shined throughout his life, and his legacy will live on through the many people he mentored. We will miss you Lucky, but we will never forget you!

To say the director of Los Alamos National Laboratory has a challenging job is a bit like calling Albert Einstein "pretty good at math." I want to thank Dr. McMillan for his years of committed, dedicated leadership in support of the national security mission and world class scientific work that is performed at LANL.     It has been a pleasure working with Charlie over the past six years to help ensure that that laboratory could deliver on these vital missions.  I wish him the best as he begins a new chapter of his life.  I look forward to working with the new leadership at LANL, and to keeping open the lines of communication and cooperation that our offices have enjoyed for so long, as we work to ensure success in LANL’s missions through the upcoming transition.

I was honored to meet some DREAMers from New Mexico today and to join my colleagues in solidarity with DREAMers across the nation. Our message to them is simple- we see you. We stand with you. We will fight for you. #DefendDACA #HereToStay

Today, I introduced the Addiction Treatment Access Improvement Act with my colleague Rep. Paul Tonko. This bill would significantly expand access to medication-assisted treatment (MAT) for opioid use disorder, particularly among vulnerable populations such as pregnant women and postpartum mothers struggling with addiction.  More than 64,000 people in the U.S. died of drug overdoses in 2016, the deadliest year on record. That number represents an increase of more than 20 percent over the previous year. Just one fifth of the patients who need treatment are currently receiving it.  As addiction continues to devastate families across our nation, we must expand access to medication-assisted treatment and allow nurses to practice to the full extent of their licensures. Advanced Practice Nurses are an integral part of health care teams all across the country, but especially in rural states like New Mexico where thousands of families depend on advanced practice nurses for so much of their routine health care. We especially need to make it easier for pregnant and postpartum women struggling with addiction to get help. Allowing Certified Nurse Midwives to prescribe and refer for MAT treatment will expand access for addicted moms – something we need to do immediately.

I was saddened to learn of the passing of former Senator Pete Domenici, New Mexico's longest-serving senator. From his start as the Chairman of Albuquerque City Commission, now known as the Mayor of  Albuquerque, Pete Domenici fought passionately for the things he believed in and the people he represented. Senator Domenici was a formidable figure who left a lasting mark on our state. My thoughts and prayers are with his family during this difficult time. May he rest in peace.

An amendment I wrote was approved today for inclusion in the 2018 federal spending bill. The amendment provides $2 million in dedicated funding for Peer Support Paraprofessionals. Ensuring all Americans have access to affordable and high quality mental health services should not be a partisan issue – it’s simply the right thing to do.  Peer support has improved health outcomes while lowering healthcare costs. In fact, there is growing evidence that peer support-related strategies can be used as more engaging and successful solutions than current hospital and emergency care related options. Peer support programs provide individualized, managed care to those who need it the most.   The current system for treating behavioral health issues is not sufficient to serve those who need help. It is unacceptable that more than 50 percent of primary care patients with depression go undiagnosed and two-thirds of primary care providers have no ability to prescribe outpatient behavioral health for their patients. Additional, dedicated funding for peer support paraprofessionals will be essential in helping address the current lack of access to behavioral health services in our health care system.   This modest amount of funding for a community-based partnership program will make an enormous difference for millions of Americans who deserve access to behavioral health services.

On Monday, I am hosting a Medicare and Social Security resource fair at Paradise Hills Community Center in Albuquerque. This will be an opportunity for you to connect with resource partners like AARP of New Mexico, the Social Security Administration, the National Association of Insurance and Financial Advisors, and the Alliance of Retired Americans to get more information on Medicare and Social Security. Members of my staff and I will also be available to help you if you are experiencing issues with federal agencies or if you have questions about my work in Washington, DC. I hope to see you there.

As we celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month, I am proud to honor the history, culture and achievements of our Hispanic communities. In New Mexico, we know well the indelible mark that Hispanic communities have had on our culture. Our art, music, food, and traditions are all reflective of the long, proud history of more than 400 years of Hispanic influence in our state.  Hispanic Heritage Month pays tribute to the generations of Hispanic Americans who have positively influenced and enriched our nation and society. Here in New Mexico, we have had a number of tremendous Hispanic Americans who have left an indelible mark, some notable examples include:   • Dolores Huerta, the activist and labor leader who co-founded what would become the United Farm Workers Union was born in Dawson, New Mexico;  • Senator Dennis Chávez from Valencia County, was the first Hispanic elected to the US Senate where he represented our state from 1935 to 1962;  • World Hall of Fame golfer, Nancy Lopez, a graduate of Goddard High School in Roswell went onto win 48 LPGA Tour events, including three major championships and is considered one of the greats of women's golf, and its best player for more than a decade. • María Benítez the dancer, choreographer and Director of the Institute for Spanish Arts in Santa Fe. A native New Mexican, Benítez is best known for popularizing Spanish dance through the work of her company, Teatro Flamenco.  Let us join together this month to celebrate the incredible role that Hispanic leaders and Hispanic communities that have played in our state’s and our nation’s history.
It’s National Hispanic Heritage Month and time to harvest our wonderful New Mexico chile peppers. Here are a couple shots of my mom and me gathering a few fine specimens from the backyard garden!

The fight to protect our healthcare isn't over. Senate Republicans and the Trump White House have rejected a bipartisan approach that was being worked on in good faith, and are now trying to pass the worst version of Trumpcare yet --  with no CBO score & no debate.   The Graham/Cassidy bill would TAKE AWAY protections for millions with pre-existing conditions and increase costs for millions more. It ransacks Medicaid funds that seniors depend on for long-term care and allows states and insurers to reinstate lifetime limits on care. It also penalizes older Americans with an age tax that will dramatically increase premiums and other costs for people over 50.  It’s time to say NO to the worst version of Trumpcare yet!

My heart goes out to all those impacted by the two most recent natural disasters – hurricane Maria and the earthquake in Mexico. All of those in harm’s way --- and all the first-responders and others working to keep them safe -- are in my thoughts and prayers.

My staff will hold mobile office hours at Edgewood Senior Center next Friday, September 29, to speak with anyone who may need help with a federal agency. In an effort to make my staff available to anyone who may not be able to travel to one of my district offices, mobile office hours allow New Mexicans to speak with my staff about casework in their communities. My staff can assist you with questions regarding Social Security benefits, veterans’ services, and other federal programs.

Today I proudly signed a petition to bring the DREAM Act to the Floor and provide a permanent solution to allow DREAMers to remain here and continue contributing to our nation. If a majority of Members sign the petition, the House will be forced to vote on the DREAM Act. It’s time for a vote on the DREAM Act.

The scale of the disaster in Puerto Rico is completely unprecedented. That's why I joined my colleagues today to demand that Congress and the White House do more to help the people of Puerto Rico.  Right now, one million Puerto Ricans are without access to clean drinking water, nearly 12,000 people are still living in shelters and 97% of the island lacks power and reportedly only 11 of Puerto Rico’s 69 hospitals have power.   Behind each of these numbers are American citizens who are suffering. We have a responsibility to deploy every asset and spend every dollar needed to save lives. Now is not the time to declare that, “everything is fine.” Now is the time to do everything in our power to help the people of Puerto Rico.

If your DACA status expires between now and March 5, 2018, you need to submit renewal applications as soon as possible in order to make the October 5, 2017 deadline. Nationwide, more than 140,000 DACA recipients can renew their status for a full two years if you apply before October 5. #DREAMers should be sure to mail their renewal applications by Oct 3rd to make sure they are received by the Oct 5th deadline→ https://goo.gl/BDvFSJ #ProtectDREAMers

We were all deeply saddened to learn that one of the fatalities in the Las Vegas, Nevada shooting was one of our own – an employee at Miyamura High School in Gallup. My thoughts and prayers are with her family and all the families of the victims of this tragic shooting.  While the details are still coming in, I grieve for the innocent victims shot in this horrific and senseless act of violence. This tragedy has touched us all -- with lives disrupted and futures cut short.

145.5 million people are at risk because of Equifax’s failure to protect their most sensitive financial and personal data. American consumers deserve answers about what caused the breach and what Equifax is doing to prevent this from happening again. #Equifax must also commit to compensating consumers who suffer harm as a consequence of this breach. I recently took a small step in that direction by introducing the Free Credit Freeze Act to allow consumers to protect themselves by freezing and unfreezing their credit at no charge. It is unconscionable that Equifax failed so spectacularly to protect people’s most sensitive personal data; it is even more reprehensible that the same company would profit from the pain they have caused.

Instead of bringing up the DREAM Act or bills to improve crumbling infrastructure or create jobs, the House GOP Leadership has today called for a vote to restrict women’s access to the full range of healthcare services. It’s the 5th such vote this year & 21st vote to attack women’s health since Jan. 2015 Time to #StopTheBans

I was proud to stand with my Congressional colleagues on the steps of the Capitol today to say enough is enough when it comes to gun violence. We must put our heads together to find common sense solutions that will #EndGunViolence.

If you live in Sandoval County please be prepared for severe weather tonight and tomorrow. You can call the Sandoval County Fire Department between 8 am and 5 pm for empty sand bags at 505-867-0245 or 505-891-7226 after hours. In the event of an emergency, you should still call 911.

House GOP waited until the funding deadline passed and are now forcing a false choice between kids and seniors. We should NOT steal billions from Medicare to pay for the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP). Seniors and kids BOTH deserve health care! #ExtendCHIP

I have introduced legislation to promote the advancement of smart cities with Congresswoman Suzan DelBene and Senator Maria Cantwell. Smart infrastructure has the potential to make our communities safer, more efficient, healthier, and more sustainable. But these advances shouldn’t just be reserved for major cities and Silicon Valley. Our legislation will help guarantee that smaller and rural communities aren’t left behind and will prevent the creation of a new digital divide by testing smart infrastructure solutions in communities of all sizes. The bill also provides assistance to communities that want to implement and develop these solutions, and will promote the development of a technology skilled workforce.

Earlier this week, our country witnessed the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history. According to reports, the shooter used a device known as a “bump stock,” which can be attached to a semi-automatic weapon to rapidly accelerate its rate of fire.   Although obtaining a fully automatic weapon is extremely difficult and prohibited in many states, it is possible to purchase devices which modify a semi-automatic weapon so that it fires at near-automatic speeds of hundreds of rounds per minute.  A bump stock, which allows a shooter to fire a semi-automatic weapon at a rate of 400 to 800 rounds per minute, is readily available for purchase online and legal to buy.    We must address the epidemic of gun violence and prevent more mass shootings in the U.S.  That is why I am co-sponsoring legislation (H.R.3947) introduced by Rep David Cicilline (D-RI) that will prohibit the manufacture, possession, sale or transfer of bump stocks and devices like them which are designed to convert a semi-automatic weapon into the near equivalent of a fully automatic machine gun.

I want to note the passing and commemorate the extraordinary life of David E. Patterson Sr. of Rio Rancho, who I had the honor of meeting a couple years ago. David was among an elite group of U.S. Marines who helped create the only unbroken code in modern military history.   As one of the Navajo Code Talkers, David and other Navajos coded and decoded classified military dispatches during WWII using a code derived from their native tongue. The Code Talkers took part in every Marine assault in the Pacific, from Guadalcanal in 1942 to Okinawa in 1945, including the Marshall Islands, Kwajalein, Iwo Jima, and Saipan, and their work contributed significantly to the Allies’ ultimate victory over Japan.   After the war, David attended college in Oklahoma and New Mexico, becoming a social worker. He married and raised his family on the reservation in Shiprock, N.M., and worked for the Navajo Nation's Division of Social Services until retiring in 1987. He was awarded the Silver Congressional Medal of Honor in 2001 and until last year, volunteered in a Shiprock school on the Navajo Reservation as a foster grandparent. Mr Patterson was 90.  It is hard to overstate the role that the Navajo Code Talkers played during the war. The commander of the Marine assault on Iwo Jima once said, "Were it not for the Navajos, the Marines would never have taken Iwo Jima."  Because the code talkers’ role was kept classified for many years, men like David returned heroes, but without a hero’s welcome.  My thoughts and prayers are with his family, friends and all who loved him. Our nation is in his debt.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is seeking dedicated workers to join the FEMA recovery team, as temporary locally-hired workers to serve the following areas:  • Florida: To apply for open positions, create an account at employflorida.com and use the keyword: FEMA. More information for job-seekers and employers can be found on the Hurricane Irma Recovery Jobs Portal (https://irma.employflorida.com/vosnet/)  • Puerto Rico: Those who wish to apply should email their resume to fema-workforce-caribbean@fema.dhs.gov and include the words “Puerto Rico” in the subject line. For those applicants without internet access, they should submit resumes in a sealed envelope at any post office in Puerto Rico marked “FEMA Jobs.” The U.S. Post Service will deliver resumes to the FEMA recovery team in Puerto Rico.   • Texas: Job-seekers should register at WorkinTexas.com, the Texas Workforce Commission’s website, where application instructions are posted. In partnership with the Texas Workforce Commission, the National Labor Exchange identifies positions here: (http://us.jobs/indexingrequest.asp?phase=3&state=HH) to assist Texan employers with recruitment needs related to Hurricane Harvey.  For more information or if you are interested in joining FEMA as a Temporary Local Hire, applicants can search positions on FEMA’s Hurricane Workforce page (https://careers.fema.gov/hurricane). For additional information on temporary local hire positions, contact FEMA Region II, IV, or IV Office (https://www.fema.gov/regional-contact-information).

Congress has called on Equifax executives to testify to the circumstances that led to a massive data breach this summer and to explain exactly what they are doing to protect consumers in response. Thus far, I have not been satisfied by Equifax’s response to these inquiries. That is why I sent a letter to the Interim Chairman and CEO of Equifax asking for them to answer questions and address several of my ongoing concerns. You can read that letter below. With over 145 million people at risk because of Equifax’s failures, it is past time that they finally provide the American people with some clear answers.    Because of my concerns, I also recently introduced the Free Credit Freeze Act to allow consumers to protect themselves by freezing and unfreezing their credit at no charge. Credit reporting agencies currently charge consumers fees each time they freeze or thaw their credit reports. Consumers should have a reliable, cost-free way to protect themselves when their sensitive personal information is compromised. You can learn more about this bill here: https://lujan.house.gov/press-releases/lujan-introduces-legislation-to-help-consumers-protect-their-credit-following-a-data-breach/

Today is sad day for New Mexico.  Music legend Al “Hurricane” Sanchez has passed away. His music touched so many in a career that spanned decades.   Al Hurricane moved us through music that became a part of our daily lives, and he was present, either in person or through his music at countless family celebrations, weddings, birthdays and even helped us mourn our loved ones.   My thoughts and prayers today are with his family and friends. His memory will live on through his unforgettable music and his remarkable family.

Today, I teamed up with U.S. Senator Brian Schatz (D-HI) to introduce the State Public Option Act, bicameral legislation to create a Medicaid-based public health care option to provide Americans with a new high-quality, low-cost choice when purchasing health insurance. The bill already has more than 35 cosponsors in both the House and Senate including my New Mexico colleagues, Sen. Tom Udall, Sen. Martin Heinrich and Congresswoman Michelle Lujan Grisham.  Our goal with this bill is simple – to expand the availability of low-cost, high-quality health plans to all Americans by establishing a state public option through Medicaid that would be available to everyone.  Our bill builds on a system that already works. We think our approach has several advantages – namely, it would positively impact Americans at all income levels – but especially middle-class and working class families, so it is targeted at those who face some of the greatest challenges.  This bill will also help consumers in those parts of the country that find themselves with only one insurance carrier or fear that they will be left with no insurance options. Medicaid is available in every county in every state in the nation, meaning that this approach reaches everyone.  To learn more, go to: https://lujan.house.gov/press-releases/lujan-introduces-bicameral-health-care-public-option-legislation/

Today I voted against a reckless Republican budget proposal that hurts seniors and families by promising to repeal the Affordable Care Act, cutting Medicare by almost $500 billion and Medicaid by nearly $1 trillion. The budget also hurts workers, college students and kids by slashing vital investments in infrastructure, Pell Grants, and Head Start – all in order to fast track fiscally irresponsible tax cuts for the wealthiest, while raising taxes on the middle class.

October 28, 2017 is National Prescription Drug Take Back Day. You can dispose of your unused and expired drugs safely at locations all around New Mexico. To find a location near you, visit the link below and enter your address. Locations are open from 10 am-2 pm today. https://takebackday.dea.gov/#collection-locator

My staff will hold mobile office hours at Project Y in Los Alamos today, from 10:30 am to 11:30 am, to speak with anyone who may need help with a federal agency. In an effort to make my staff available to anyone who may not be able to travel to one of my district offices, mobile office hours allow New Mexicans to speak with my staff about casework in their communities. My staff can assist you with questions regarding Social Security benefits, veterans’ services, and other federal programs.

Along with all Americans, I was shocked and saddened by the despicable attack on innocent people in New York earlier today. My heart goes out to the families of those killed and wounded. All of New York City is in my prayers.

This is your chance to make changes that work best for you and your family. To get covered during open enrollment, visit bewellnm.com. This year’s enrollment period is shorter than in the past, so be sure to visit bewellnm.com or call toll-free at 1-833-862-3935 for more information.   As part of open enrollment, my staff will be holding Mobile Office Hours tomorrow from 9 am to 12 pm at Mary Esther Gonzales Senior Center. Representatives will be present from Aging and Long-Term Services to answer any questions you may have about open enrollment.

Open Enrollment has now officially begun. This is the time to #GetCovered and choose a plan that works best for you and your family. Open Enrollment is shorter this year than in the past – November 1 to December 15. Don’t miss your chance to #GetCovered. Visit bewellnm.com or call toll-free at 1-833-862-3935 for more information.

Today, I joined 174 members of Congress in an amici brief to the Supreme Court supporting a gay couple who was denied service by a bakery. Every person deserves the right to receive medical care, eat a meal and shop in a department store without worry they will be refused service. And that is exactly what this case is about: denying a minority group access to businesses that open their doors to the public. The fight for LGBT equality did not end with marriage equality. I will continue to help lead the charge until all Americans are free from discrimination.

I joined my Congressional colleagues on the steps of the US Capitol to remind the Trump administration of its unfilled obligations to the people of Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands. Hurricane Maria was a disaster of unprecedented scope and six weeks later, 75% of residents on the US Virgin Islands do not have power, students still have not returned to school, and hospitals remain unopened. Hundreds are dead and people are still dying! In Puerto Rico nearly 20% of residents are without clean water and two thirds of the island is still without power and has been without power for over 40 days. This is completely unacceptable and we must do more to help. At the very least, we must lift the cap and waive the match on Puerto Rico’s Medicaid program – it’s what we did for Katrina and it’s what we should do here. Not adequately funding Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Island Medicaid program will only make this crisis worse. One in four islanders’ will lose their medical care if we don’t act NOW.
Join me tomorrow at Flying Star in Corrales for a community discussion on my Medicaid Public Option bill and the Ryan/McConnell tax plan. I hope to see you in Corrales tomorrow from 2-3:30 pm.
