Thank you to everyone who attended my town hall yesterday in Corrales. I appreciated the opportunity to talk with you about my work in Congress and to learn about your concerns.

Every November, during Native American Heritage Month, we come together to recognize the timeless history and heritage of Native Americans in New Mexico and across the country. The foundation of our entire nation has been indelibly shaped by the language, culture, art, and faith of our indigenous brothers and sisters. It is one of my greatest honors to represent the 19 Pueblos and two Apache nations of New Mexico, as well as the Eastern Agency of the Navajo Nation.

Congratulations to Santa Fe public school Wood Gormley Elementary School on their selection by the Department of Education as a 2017 Blue Ribbon School, a celebration of schools demonstrating that all students can achieve to high levels. Wood Gormley Elementary was chosen as an Exemplary Achievement Gap Closing School for their progress in closing achievement gaps among student subgroups. The student body of Wood Gormley is a representative cross-section of the cultural and linguistic diversity of Santa Fe, leading teachers to invite parents, guardians and volunteers to share their respective cultures with students. This multicultural approach pushes Wood Gormley children beyond tolerance of difference to an appreciation of difference. Congratulations to the students, educators, families, and communities who have all played a role in earning Wood Gormley this distinction.

It was a pleasure meeting with Pueblo of Acoma Governor Riley today to discuss the STOP Act- legislation I introduced to help protect tribal cultural and sacred objects from being sold illegally in the US and abroad. I look forward to working with Governor Riley and the Pueblo of Acoma to help pass this bill.

This Friday, I will be moderating a panel of local experts to discuss the opioid crisis in northern New Mexico and what programs are helping our communities begin the long road to recovery. If you have questions about this health crisis, I encourage you to attend the panel discussion. In addition to our panel discussion, you can also participate in a naloxone training session. Naloxone is a medication designed to reverse opioid overdose and could save the life of countless New Mexicans.

Don't forget- today I'm hosting a naloxone training event followed by a panel on the opioid crisis in northern New Mexico. If you are concerned about this health crisis, I encourage you to attend the panel discussion and training session. Naloxone is a medication designed to reverse opioid overdose and could help save the lives of countless New Mexicans.

In recognition of Veterans Day, I have introduced two bills to address the needs of our nation’s veterans. My bills would raise the minimum wage for veterans attending school through the GI Bill, and reauthorize a program that provides rental assistance to Native American veterans experiencing homelessness. As we gather this weekend in communities large and small to honor those who have served our country, we must remember that the true measure of how we honor our veterans will be determined by how we treat them when they return home. We must ensure that our veterans have access to the benefits they have been promised, and are equipped to pursue successful careers when their service is complete. The two bills I have introduced will help homeless Native veterans and veterans who are supporting themselves as they attend school following their service.

As we gather in communities large and small on Veteran's Day to honor those who have served in the Armed Services, we remember the spirit of duty, service and sacrifice that has protected our country and the values we all hold dear for more than 240 years. Our state has a long tradition of serving the nation during times of war. Generations of New Mexicans have answered the call to selflessly serve. It is truly humbling to think of those who answered the call to defeat tyranny, to stand against terror, and to protect the freedoms and the liberties we hold most dear.  To to all of you who have proudly worn our nation’s uniform, I say “thank you.” Thank you for taking that time away from your families, for spending those long days away from home. Thank you for volunteering for a duty that took you to the ends of the earth, and in many cases, put you in harm’s way.

Today I was able to pay tribute to a leader, an advocate and a warrior – Sergeant Elaine Mitchell, Commander of the Disabled Veterans of America in Rio Rancho when I presented her with a flag that had been flown over the US Capitol in her honor.  Sergeant Mitchell has served her fellow veterans with the same spirit of duty, honor and selflessness with which she served her country, and she has distinguished herself by her service to others. This year she is being honored with the DAV’s Lifetime Achievement Award.
NA

The Republican Tax Scam hurts seniors and families by eliminating the medical expense deduction that millions of Americans rely on—including 120,000 New Mexicans. I spoke on the floor of the House of Representatives today to share the story of one New Mexican family who needs this deduction. Watch below to hear Lisa’s story.

Yesterday, House Republicans passed a GOP tax scam that will raise taxes on millions of hard-working American families in order to hand deficit-exploding giveaways to the wealthiest few. Read more about the impact on middle-class families: https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/16/gop-tax-bill-would-spike-obamacare-premiums-nearly-2000-for-families.html
Happy Thanksgiving to you and your family! Wishing you all a safe and happy holiday.

The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office has analyzed the Senate version of the GOP tax scam and found that just like the House bill, it increases the fortunes of the wealthiest Americans on the backs of middle-class and working families. A couple important takeaways:  “By 2019, Americans earning less than $30,000 a year would be worse off under the Senate bill. By 2021, Americans earning $40,000 or less would be net losers . . . On the flip side, millionaires and those earning $100,000 to $500,000 would be big beneficiaries.”   and   “The CBO has calculated that health insurance premiums would rise if this bill becomes law, leading 4 million Americans to lose health insurance by 2019 and 13 million to lose insurance by 2027.”  Read the whole article: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/11/26/senate-gop-tax-bill-hurts-the-poor-more-than-originally-thought-cbo-finds/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_cbo-tax-915pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.68fb426ff955

Today’s racially derogatory remarks by President Trump regarding Senator Warren are mean-spirited, insulting and impossible to interpret as anything other than a slur against an entire people. They are beneath the dignity of the office that Mr. Trump holds and are especially insensitive given the setting in which they were delivered, one designed to honor the Navajo Code Talkers’ role in World War II.   I have met many of the Navajo Nation Code Talkers and their families, and these remarks diminish the heroic role they had in ensuring our nation’s freedom.  It is a sad day in our country when words spoken by the President serve to undermine the Code Talkers place in history.

I am pleased to announce that I have nominated 29 students from northern New Mexico for admission to the United States Service Academies as part of the freshman class of 2018. Our state has a long tradition of serving our nation in all the branches of our military.  Having the chance to recommend some of New Mexico’s best and brightest young people to become our nation’s future military leaders is a distinct honor for me each year. I am very proud of each and every one of these students, who have demonstrated a commitment to service, the drive to succeed and tremendous dedication to our state and our nation. Read the full list of nominated students here:

Last Congress, my colleagues and I worked together to pass two bipartisan bills – the Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act and 21st Century Cures Act. But we must do more. That’s why I introduced legislation to extend funding to combat the opioid epidemic for an additional 5 years. A five-year extension of this funding is the minimum we should be doing. Because this drug crisis is tearing apart the fabric of communities across the country, we must work together to ensure that this important funding does not expire. Too many people are suffering without access to meaningful support systems.

I was proud to champion the creation of the Sabinoso Wilderness and am pleased that the long process of providing access has finally been completed. I want to thank the Bureau of Land Management, the Wilderness Land Trust and other local groups who worked diligently to see this effort through. New Mexico is known as the Land of Enchantment because of our people, beautiful landscapes, clear skies, and fresh air. By preserving this land and providing access to Sabinoso, New Mexicans can enjoy these areas for generations to come.

On Saturday, I met Rowan Nadon, the winner of the third annual Congressional App Challenge.   Rowan, a sophomore at Santa Fe High School, designed an app called "Smart Security," which allows users to monitor home security footage from anywhere in the world with internet access. The app uses facial recognition technology to detect unknown people in the video stream and send users an alert with the option to review the video stream.  Join me in congratulating Rowan on his win!

Congratulations to Kashon Harrison of Fruitland, New Mexico, who won the Foot Locker Cross Country Championships West Regional meet this weekend in Walnut, California.   Harrison, a junior at Kirtland Central High School, finished first with a time of 15:38.4.  The top 10 boys and the top 10 girls qualified to compete against runners from the Northeast, South and Midwest Regionals in the Cross Country National Finals, on Saturday, Dec. 9 in San Diego.   Good luck Kashon!

The Trump administration's decision to dramatically decrease the size of Bears Ears National Monument despite vast public opposition is an attack on our national monuments. Our public lands must be protected and preserved. I have co-sponsored legislation to safeguard Bears Ears National Monument from this unprecedented attack and preserve its 1.35 million acres of wilderness and over 100,000 Native American archaeological and cultural sites for future generations.

My heart breaks for the victims and the families of the tragic shooting at Aztec High School this morning. While the details are still coming in, we grieve for the innocent victims shot in this senseless act of violence.  This is just the latest example of gun violence that has filled us with anguish and has left another community reeling. Too many lives have been disrupted and too many futures cut short. We must come together to heal, but this tide of violence must not continue.

My Democratic colleagues and I favor tax reform that prioritizes middle class families and puts working Americans first. Unfortunately, this bill gives 83 percent of tax cuts to corporations and the top 1 percent. The GOP tax scam explodes the deficit and sticks our children with the bill, all while requiring Medicare to be slashed by $25 billion.  If that’s not bad enough, this bill will lead to an increase of health care premiums across America and gives new tax breaks to companies shipping jobs overseas. People are smarter than House Republicans are giving them credit for. They see this bill for the scam it is.

Today, along with fellow House member Rep. Joe Wilson (R-SC) and U.S. Senators Chris Coons (D-DE.) and Lindsey Graham (R-SC), I introduced bicameral, bipartisan legislation to drive private investment in new energy tech. Our bill will help bring innovative new products to market faster and lead to more opportunities/jobs that address tomorrow’s energy challenges.  Recent declines in research funding have resulted in a steep decline in energy technology startup companies. The non-profit foundation created by this bill will serve as a framework to organize, connect, and coordinate partners from government, industry and the venture capital sectors. Similar foundations at the National Institutes of Health, the Centers for Disease Control, and the U.S. Department of Agriculture have all demonstrated that they can raise tens of millions of private sector dollars towards cutting-edge research and innovation. This foundation will help grow our economy and create jobs, leverage the work of our national laboratories and enable new products and services to come to market more quickly.  Find information here: https://lujan.house.gov/press-releases/congressman-lujan-and-colleagues-introduce-bipartisan-bicameral-bill-to-help-drive-investment-in-new-energy-technologies/
